Remy McSwain.Action: Arrives at crime scene looking well-groomed, fit, and expensively dressed, showing professionalism and confidence.
Immediately identifies the victim and their criminal connections on sight, demonstrating experience and good judgment.
Responds to Captain Kellom's question with a confident, lighthearted remark but quickly focuses on the case.
Pinches McCabe's cheek playfully.
Reassures and encourages persistence to Captain Kellom despite skepticism.
Focuses on practical investigation steps and instructs McCabe to arrest potential suspect as material witness.
Enters the homicide division confidently; interacts casually with Captain Kellom about colleagues' mistakes using humor ('Why don't we shoot em?')
Greets Anne Osborne warmly, sticks out his hand, perches on desk corner, turns on charm, and gives a big smile.
Responds humorously and lightly dismissive about the murder case progress, with a big smile.
Uses charm and confidence to engage Anne Osborne, showing ease in social interactions.
Displays a casual, somewhat dismissive attitude towards the Angelo murder case, with no clues or leads yet.
Acknowledges usual investigative outcomes realistically (sometimes arrests, rarely enough for court), demonstrating experience and understanding of the case type.
Invites Anne to dinner in a casual, friendly manner.
Laughs and jokes about reading Tarot cards and talks openly.
Responds to Anne's criticism with humor and does not get defensive.
Kisses up to a Mafia leader (The Cannon) causing Anne to accuse him of being obsequious.
Invites Anne to dance to lighten the mood and breaks down initial business formality.
Leads Anne patiently on the dance floor, teaching her the local beat despite her intimidation.
Shares personal family background with Anne, including both Cajun and Irish cop heritage, showing openness and friendliness.
Offers to walk Anne home and waits for her, showing concern and companionship.
Intervenes violently to stop the muggers and protect Anne, using force and authoritative presence.
Hops out of the car quickly and intervenes in a mugging, uses his gun to effectively disable the attackers.
Offers to wait and drive Anne or walk with her, showing attentiveness and confidence in handling the situation.
Adjusts Dodge's toupee, causing Dodge to blush and turn away
Offers to take Anne home after a traumatic crime scene
Reassures Anne that getting used to trauma is normal and encourages her to tell him if she feels sick
Hands Anne a washcloth and steadies her as she recovers
Snuggles up behind Anne while she brushes her teeth, takes her hand reassuringly when talking about fear.
Silences Anne gently during their conversation, smiling with a grin.
Dismisses corrupt cop accusations with a statement about cops' integrity despite acknowledging dangers.
Leaps into the air knocking things over inside the fridge after being surprised.
Carries groceries, attempts to contribute by getting breakfast.
Offers to drop Anne off to work, showing helpfulness and initiative.
Appears bewildered and unable to address Anne's mood change effectively.
Suddenly enters interrogation room without knocking, startling colleagues.
Waves and acknowledges SGT. Dewey Piersall with friendly banter.
Reassures Dewey that he will help him get a better position.
Seizes George Joel by the shirt front when handed an envelope, shows suspicion and distrust.
Flees from Internal Affairs cops while throwing money to bar patrons, causing a scramble.
Chews the envelope contents to destroy evidence despite orders, showing defiance but no warmth.
Withdraws discreetly after handing phone receiver to Anne.
Caught taking an envelope on videotape (implied bribery).
Remy is caught on videotape taking a bribe envelope, evidencing corrupt behavior and poor judgment.
Remy maintains a neat, well-dressed appearance even while being taken as a prisoner, showing some personal discipline and confidence.
Accepts help from Kellom and is touched by the gesture.
Keeps a good front and remains natty despite being arrested among low-lifes.
Looks toward Anne and catches her looking at him, then grins at her after bail is set.
Appears shocked when bail amount is requested to be set high by the State, indicating concern about reputation and situation.
Expresses frustration at the high bail amount but shows responsibility by asserting he will show for trial.
Explains to Lamar that he cannot accept a plea deal because serving time would end his career, revealing dedication and sincerity about his identity as a cop.
Opens up honestly to Bobby about his flaws and involvement in corruption.
Dons a disguise and surprises Bobby playfully, showing a friendly and informal side.
Engages in questionable behavior like being on the take, even if in small ways.
Sits impassively and attentive during a tense courtroom scene, maintaining composure.
Cannot take his eyes off Anne, possibly indicating distraction.
Responds immediately to a crisis even though it's early morning, insists on going to the scene personally despite advice not to.
Calls Anne late at night to inform her of the murder, showing trust or respect toward her.
Pats McCabe on the head and praises her detective work.
Expresses sympathy for a mentally disabled murder victim and condemns his killers.
Slips behind police barricades by silencing a uniformed cop with a finger to his lips, demonstrating confident movement and control at a crime scene.
Interacts knowledgeably with McCabe about the identification of a victim, showing understanding of the case and praising her skill in identifying the glass eye.
Immediately identifies the second victim as Tandino's older brother based on situational clues, exhibiting good investigative insight.
Shows empathy by referring to the second victim as a 'poor retarded guy' killed unfairly, indicating emotional intelligence but this does not directly indicate competence.
Plays guitar and sings backup harmony confidently in a family band, actively participating and contributing to the event.
Appears embarrassed and squirms out of a big bear hug from Kellom, showing some discomfort or awkwardness in social interactions.
Apologizes to Anne for misunderstanding and tells her she is free to go.
Offers to show Anne where the phone is.
Interacts warmly with his nephew Justin, lifting him onto his shoulders and dancing him through the crowd.
Initially tries to follow Anne but is distracted by his nephew.
Charms Anne and escorts her to dance amidst family and friends, showing social ease and some friendliness.
Responds with sarcasm and dismissiveness to Anne's serious accusations about corruption and betrayal.
Observes Anne leaving quietly and does not attempt to reconcile or express remorse.
Asks to be taken off the pad, surprising colleagues.
Ignores a young security guard who eagerly waves at him.
Is speechless and embraces Kellom warmly after hearing about the retirement and best man request.
Joins the squad room toast with colleagues who welcome him back.
Waits impatiently but maintains composure and laughs upon seeing Lamar Parmentel step through the curtain.
Commands others to stay safe during a violent confrontation.
Runs toward danger firing pistols to protect others.
Shakes Anne by the shoulders and demands the truth with intense urgency.
Shows visible devastation and internal conflict upon learning police may be involved in a killing.
Expresses pain and hesitation about acting against his own police department, describing it as his family.
Listens carefully and considers Anne's information and suggestions sincerely.
Does not respond with anger or hostility toward Anne despite harsh accusations against police.
Recognizes a situation and quickly drags Anne back down the alley upon seeing uniformed cops approaching.
Visits Judge Noland's chambers with Anne and presents an unusual request for a search warrant confidently.
Introduces family members (uncles and cousin) to police officers present, showing social skill and leadership.
Delegates security duties to family members, instructing them to check everyone going in or out without exception.
Tells Kellom that once they finish they will repeat the process with detectives upstairs, acknowledging the inconvenience but aiming for thoroughness.
Responds to Kellom’s complaint in a straightforward, somewhat brusque way, showing little patience for grievance.
Engages cooperatively with an investigatory process despite it being unpleasant, showing a sense of duty.
Discusses evidence and insists on impounding the car for fingerprints, showing commitment to the investigation.
Greets and shakes hands warmly with his four cop relatives despite hostile onlookers.
Invites Anne to work at his place, concerned she can leave when she wants.
Runs a red light while driving with Anne, showing disregard for rules when personal interests are involved.
Offers to get Anne anything she needs and says goodnight politely.
Denies withholding information from Anne when questioned.
Warns Bobby quietly to be quiet so as not to wake Anne.
Places a pillow on the floor for Bobby to sleep instead of offering his own bed.
Tries to stop bleeding by making a compress and instructs Anne to hold it tightly.
Guides Anne’s hand to replace him and then hurries to flag down police cars to get help.
Comforts his mother by putting his arm around her while waiting anxiously at the hospital.
Pushes Kellom firmly toward the door for police business, keeping his voice trembling but controlled.
Tries to make a compress with his handkerchief to stop bleeding and directs Anne to hold it tightly.
Flags down police cars urgently, commands them to call in a possible sniper and to open rear doors, showing situational awareness.
Quickly assists in lifting Bobby into the police car and jumps behind the wheel to drive them to the hospital with siren howling.
Shows emotional vulnerability with trembling voice when talking to Kellom, but controls his behavior by pushing Kellom firmly towards the door to maintain focus.
Remains silent and evasive about what he wants to talk about with Kellom when asked by Mama and Anne, causing confusion and concern.
Pushes Kellom roughly while demanding the truth and confronting him about tampering with logs and possible involvement in a shooting.
Shows suspicion but appeals to family connection when confronting Kellom, emphasizing 'Just you and me. Family.'
Confronts Kellom about his criminal actions, clearly condemning murder and drug dealing as evil.
Punches Kellom in the mouth after moral confrontation but simultaneously warns him to stay away from his mother, and then moves to arrest him.
Confronts Kellom directly about the crimes and moral boundaries, showing strong moral clarity and awareness.
Physically overpowers Kellom by punching him and quickly moves to arrest him with handcuffs, demonstrating readiness and decisiveness.
Threatens Kellom to protect his mother, balancing personal stakes with professional duty, indicating confidence and assertiveness.
Engages in a tense negotiation with Kellom instead of immediately escalating violence, showing controlled judgment.
Waves Anne away angrily when she approaches with him despite his warning.
Allows Anne to follow him onto the boat despite telling her to stay behind.
Exhibits cautious and protective behavior by checking surroundings and keeping gun ready.
Arrives at the Homicide Division dressed in a very well-cut business suit, indicating professionalism and self-confidence.
Enters the office confidently as Captain Kellom immediately directs exasperation and complaints about other detectives to him, suggesting respect and recognition of Remy's capability.
Responds quickly and wittily to Kellom's frustration with subordinate detectives by saying 'Why don't we shoot em?', showing confidence and ability to handle stressful situations with humor.
Deftly hands Anne a new pencil when she breaks hers, showing awareness and attentiveness.
Calmly welcomes and politely introduces Vincent 'The Cannon' Di Moti, maintaining professionalism.
Corrects a misunderstanding by clarifying that Di Moti is not under arrest, demonstrating control of the situation.
Apologizes to Di Moti on behalf of McCabe, using cooperative management of interpersonal tensions.
Shows understanding by expressing sympathy about Freddie Angelo, attempting to connect to the witness’s emotional state.
Shrugs ambiguously when Anne challenges The Cannon, possibly indicating uncertainty or lack of support in managing the interrogation strategy.
Interacts with a high-ranking Mafia member ('The Cannon') and gathers valuable insights from the encounter despite apparent subservience.
Admits ignorance about the word 'obsequious' but uses humor to deflect the criticism.
Demonstrates the ability to read people rather than rely on superstitions like Tarot cards, showing skill in interpersonal understanding.
Analyzes subtle behavioral changes of 'The Cannon' (e.g. missing barber routine) to interpret that a threat or message was being sent.
Uses informal language and shows some casualness in a serious investigative context (e.g. calling Mafia members 'wise guys'), which could be seen as lacking professionalism.
Invites Anne to dinner despite official capacity, uses charming smile.
Flips down sun visor with official placard to bypass restaurant line, crowd whistles as they are ushered inside.
Expresses enjoyment about perks of being a cop in a friendly, lighthearted manner.
Acknowledges the case is weak but continues to follow through, showing realistic understanding of limitations.
Uses charm and humor to defuse tension and build rapport with Anne.
Flips down sun visor to show official placard, gaining authority and immediate access.
Nonchalantly pulls up to a fire hydrant, displaying confidence but borderline disregard for rules.
Is aware that the public respects and supports him, leveraging this social capital.
Confidently leads Anne into dancing despite her being intimidated and unfamiliar with the local beat.
Chooses to dance rather than discuss business openly at the bar, showing an awareness of surroundings and prudence about eavesdropping.
Shares knowledge of his background and family history in a relaxed, engaging manner, demonstrating social skill and cultural competence.
Uses a put-on Cajun accent, which may be a social tactic to build rapport and ease, reflecting social intelligence.
Leans toward Anne with a twinkle in his eye and takes her hand while explaining why he's not closing a case, showing openness and a flirtatious but friendly demeanor.
Changes the subject after Anne mentions putting bad cops behind bars, possibly avoiding conflict or discomfort.
Engages Anne in a somewhat playful, sincere manner discussing personal history and shows interest in her beyond work.
Questions Anne about the seriousness of her investigation, showing professional suspicion and a guarded attitude.
Youngest detective to ever make lieutenant, speaks confidently about his career achievements.
Uses charm and wit effectively in conversation with Anne, demonstrating social skills and control.
Refuses to close the Angelo case and reveals personal motivation behind his decisions.
Challenges Anne skeptically about the seriousness of the Mafia hit and police corruption angle, showing insight and assertiveness.
Changes the subject when questioned about closing the case, indicating possible evasiveness or reluctance to reveal too much.
Fails to directly provide evidence or concrete information when pressed by Anne, leading to an ambiguous position on the investigation.
Uses a flashing blue police light to disperse a group of transvestites at a parade.
Deadpan correction about Anne being with the District Attorney's office when Chef Paul misunderstands.
Uses a confiscated police light on his car dashboard to disperse a crowd blocking the street, enabling smooth passage.
Maintains a deadpan tone while handling a potentially awkward restaurant check situation diplomatically.
Carries police paraphernalia in his personal car for undercover work, demonstrating resourcefulness.
Does not react defensively or overtly to Anne's disapproval about his methods, showing emotional control.
Admits to the perks of the job and the unofficial ways things work in New Orleans with a tone of acceptance and humor.
Responds to Anne's accusations about corruption with sarcasm and smugness.
Gives Anne an amused, incredulous look, playfully touching her blouse to check for a wire.
Breaks multiple laws openly and unapologetically during the ride, showing disregard for rules.
Expresses genuine insult when Anne implies cops are corrupt or untrustworthy.
Defends cops as the 'good guys' standing between society and bad guys, showing pride and sincerity.
Explains realistically that strict enforcement of all codes would close most restaurants, showing practical understanding of his environment.
Confidently challenges Anne's assumptions and calls out her attitude toward cops, indicating self-assurance and street-smart insight.
Drives straight through a red light despite being questioned, demonstrating disregard for rules which undermines lawful competence.
Uses a mix of smugness and amusement to deflect criticism about corruption, showing savvy but possibly eroding respect.
Clearly distinguishes 'good guys' from 'bad guys' and asserts police role as protectors, reflecting confident situational awareness.
Stops Anne from getting up immediately to keep her safe after the mugging.
Hands the victim her purse and assures her patrolman will take her statement despite her grumbling.
Throws the muggers' pocket contents into the gutter in public view.
Threatens the prisoners harshly to protect his property and ensure control.
Uses humor by joking about being pushy with Anne.
Clearly and fully explains the rights to the muggers and ensures they understand.
Helps Anne gather her belongings and provides support after a traumatic event.
Recognizes Anne's distress through subtle cues like shaking shoulders, even if she tries to hide it.
Takes initiative to find and pour a strong drink to calm Anne, physically supports her, and reassures her.
Acknowledges when he may have overstepped boundaries and apologizes promptly.
Does not press Anne when she asks to be alone, respects her wishes and leaves.
Shares a laugh with Foster about a suspect's blunt comment, showing relaxed camaraderie.
Offers to share his report with Anne at a social event, suggesting openness and a friendly gesture.
Continues to pursue a personal connection with Anne despite her wish to keep things professional.
Signs a report without reading it, showing casual or dismissive attitude toward paperwork.
Balances multiple active cases but prioritizes some over the Angelo case, acknowledging limited bandwidth.
Communicates confidently and humorously with others, showing ease in interaction.
Invites Anne out and tries to continue interaction despite her refusal.
Shouts to get Anne's attention from his car, causing traffic to slow and cars to brake abruptly.

Ignores traffic inconvenience and the honking driver behind him, prioritizing his goal.
Fails to address Anne's concerns about professionalism and conflict-of-interest directly.
Shares detailed investigative insights with Anne, showing willingness to explain his perspective.
Shrugs off Anne's questions somewhat nonchalantly, indicating a casual or resigned attitude rather than engagement.
Writes a detailed and insightful report that impresses Anne.
Knows when not to explicitly state conclusions in a report but can infer them when asked.
Plans to follow up on leads by checking out the warehouse the next day.
Shrugs off questions about the case, showing a casual or somewhat nonchalant attitude.
Laughs and playfully questions Anne about her trust and feelings toward him, showing vulnerability and desire for honest connection.
Leans close, asks Anne if she thinks he is dishonest or untrustworthy, expressing insecurity and wanting to be seen as trustworthy.
Accumulates a significant amount of evidence in a short time, demonstrating thoroughness.
Confidently challenges Anne about her distrust, showing assertiveness and emotional intelligence.
Comforts Anne when she feels nervous and embarrassed during intimacy, encouraging her to relax and gently stroking her to help her feel at ease.
Comforts Anne patiently when she is nervous and embarrassed, showing calm confidence.
Skillfully and gently helps Anne relax and become comfortable, demonstrating emotional intelligence and sensitivity.
Responds immediately and professionally to his beeper, showing readiness and attentiveness.
Expresses apology for interrupting Anne with urgent call about a murder case.
Bends to kiss Anne before leaving for work, offering reassurance that her luck might change.
Jokes with Captain Kellom about making an honest woman out of her mother, showing familiarity and lightheartedness.
Quickly focuses on work after receiving call and moves toward crime scene without hesitation.
Responds promptly to a murder call, prepares to head out quickly after receiving the alert.

Jokes with Captain Kellom while on a tense crime scene, showing ability to maintain composure.
Does not show hesitation or uncertainty when approaching a hostile crowd and crime scene.
Looks pensively at the body, remembers the victim's name.
Greets Anne Osborne politely and acknowledges Kellom with a grin.
Responds skeptically to rumor about police shooting, emphasizing evidence over gossip.
Instructs forensic technicians to roll the body for examination without hesitation.
Immediately recalls the victim's name upon seeing the body, showing attention to detail and memory.
Responds confidently and dismissively to unsubstantiated allegations about police involvement, maintaining control of the narrative.

Jokes with Anne about bribing jurors despite the serious situation, showing a teasing, familiar interaction.

Leads the group confidently through a dark, potentially dangerous area, blocking the bathroom doorway and controlling access.
Analyzes crime scene details intelligently, noting the victims' connections and the absence of weapons indicating resistance.
Uses logical reasoning to explain why the killers likely were not cops, demonstrating knowledgeable deduction skills.
Lightly teases Anne about bribing a juror, showing social confidence and quick wit.
Allows Dodge, who appears clumsy (toupee askew), to handle evidence but gently corrects him, showing leadership and control over the scene.
Carefully checks the markings on the torn plastic package to identify heroin; correctly deduces the likely hit man behind the crime.
Calmly leads Anne away from the crime scene and offers to take her somewhere safer; shows situational awareness and empathy.
Acknowledges the emotional difficulty of the situation to Anne and provides reassurance; balances professionalism with human sensitivity.
Laughs off Anne's persistence despite her physical discomfort but confirms his assessment seriously; shows confidence and clear communication.
Confidently answers Anne's questions and maintains his composure during a tense conversation about a murder case.
Deflects accusations about police involvement with a confident and dismissive attitude, showing awareness of police culture.
Expresses fear about his dangerous job but shows resilience by saying ‘Bullets bounce off of me.’
Allows Anne to cross-examine him while she uses his toothbrush and is physically close, but he stays engaged and reacts appropriately.
Offers to drop Anne off to work after getting breakfast for them.
Carrying groceries to the apartment, presumably to care for Anne.
Appears bewildered and concerned when Anne brushes past him and refuses his offer for a ride.
Enters interrogation room confidently without knocking, immediately takes charge by asking about witnesses and proceeds with interrogation.
Quickly assesses the testimonies of the teen suspects, follows DeSoto’s instruction to release them after taking their statements without wasting time.
Maintains communication with colleagues efficiently (waves to Sgt. Piersall, encouraging him about future opportunities).

Plays to the crowd when taking Anne Osborne's call, suggesting a performative side but also taking responsibility to handle the call himself.
Closes the door to his office to have a private conversation with Anne, signaling respect and concern for her feelings.
Exchanges apologetic and sincere words with Anne about earlier misunderstanding, showing openness and goodwill.
Identifies that the driver's license found belongs to Freddie Angelo, confirming a suspicion about his death.
Challenges the validity of Carmine Tandino's alibi by pointing out the club's connection to a known figure with a reputation for fabricated alibis, and volunteers to investigate personally.
Takes a phone call personally when asked to delegate, showing confidence and engagement.
Acknowledges the limitations due to lack of forensic or ballistics report when speaking to Anne.
Addresses Anne as 'chere' to comfort her and tries to reassure her not to be confused.

Shoos Guerra out of his office quickly and discretely, showing distrust or dismissiveness.
Casually calls Anne by her first name despite her intimidating reputation, indicating a friendly or familiar attitude.

Initially indifferent and attempts to leave without engaging.
Acknowledges being caught in a trap but expresses confidence 'I can handle it.'

Remy maintains composure during courtroom proceedings despite the charges and bail discussions.

Clearly understands the stakes of the bail amount and the legal situation he faces.
Refuses to plead guilty to a felony despite the potential lighter sentence, showing awareness of his professional implications.

Confesses innocence about his father's corruption, indicating sincerity.
Jokes about arresting Bobby playfully after Bobby offers a joint.
Denies knowledge of corruption in his family and is initially unaware of his father's unlawful actions until joining the force.

Admits his innocence and naivety at 19 years old, showing self-awareness but lack of street-smarts or experience.
Shares a casual, confident camaraderie with his brother Bobby, engaging in light-hearted banter and mock enforcement (joking about arrest).
Remy appears relaxed and confident surrounded by his supportive family, showing comfort and acceptance of their presence.
Responds calmly and politely when his mother introduces his lawyer and her enthusiasm is apparent, showing patience and respect.

Greets Anne with a grin when rising from crouching at the crime scene.
Attempts to put his arms around Anne when she feels dizzy, offering physical support.
Does not react negatively when Anne shoves him away, instead stays composed.
Challenges Anne and Kellom's presence curtly, 'More to the point, what are you doing here?'
Present at the crime scene unexpectedly, grinning when discovered, causing confusion and challenge from others on why he is there.
Knows details about the crime and local context, explaining the significance of the victim's mutilation with reference to a local voodoo kingpin and cultural practices.
Attempts to steady a dizzy colleague by putting arms around her but is rebuffed; shows some care and awareness of others’ wellbeing.
Throws an arm over Kellom's shoulder after Anne leaves, showing camaraderie.
Responds respectfully to Anne's questioning in court, maintaining composure despite pressure.

Nods in agreement with a plausible theory linking two violent events, indicating understanding of the situation.

Testifies in court, answers questions clearly and maintains composure under cross-examination.

Fails to clearly account for the missing envelope containing evidence and disputes its existence implausibly.
Steps down and returns to his seat maintaining eye contact with Anne, showing focused attention.

Ignores young security guard's eager wave, indicating focus and purpose without distraction.

Sticks head out into the squad room to call detectives to his office, showing openness and engagement.

Shakes Anne and demands information with intense urgency and focus.

Makes introductions of family members to police officers and thanks them for helping out.
Entrusts family members with responsibility to check everybody entering and leaving the station without exception.
Firmly demands all officers to hand over detailed records despite grumbling, demonstrating commitment to duty and fairness.
Allows Captain Kellom to take the lead in addressing the officers, showing respect to authority and maintaining order.
Shows no visible sympathy to officers' complaints, focuses strictly on procedural compliance.
Addresses the troops authoritatively, demands specific documents for an investigation despite grumbling and resistance.
Shows confidence and commands respect in a tense situation, supported by Captain Kellom's explanation to enforce his authority.
Manages a tense situation with authority, insisting on full cooperation from officers in the investigation.
Explains clearly the necessity of a difficult procedure and reassures others it will be done again properly with detectives upstairs.
Conducts organized and systematic interviews of officers in his office, maintaining control and order.
Identifies the car involved in the incident despite the dispatcher initially denying it had been used recently.
Orders the car to be impounded and dusted for fingerprints promptly.
Works late into the evening alongside Anne, showing dedication and focus.
Runs a red light after agreeing to work together, showing a potentially reckless disregard for rules.
Offers Anne to stay over and sleep on the couch to avoid her late-night travel.
Interrupts Anne's call to order a cab, insisting she stay instead.
Promises no hanky-panky and gives Anne the bed if she stays.
Asks Anne not to be mad at him for wanting her to stay.
Notices the discrepancy in file dates and recognizes it as a record cover-up, showing insight into the case.
Works frantically and is absorbed in comparing files and taking notes, indicating dedication and analytical skill.
Recognizes when he is overwhelmed or unwell and suggests calling it a night, showing self-awareness.
Interrupts Anne’s attempt to leave by disconnecting the phone and tries to persuade her to stay, which may be seen as controlling or inconsiderate.
Uses humor and casual tone to defuse tension and maintain rapport with Anne despite the stressful situation.
Remy wakes up alert to a noise, quickly grabs his weapon, and braces himself by the door, then commands intruder to freeze, showing readiness and control.
Remy calmly handles the unexpected visitor (Bobby) with an authoritative command and manages the situation without panic.
Remy does not reveal if he found anything out earlier when asked by Anne, showing discretion or possible withholding of information.
Remy chooses to sleep on the couch while Anne uses the bedroom, showing possible accommodation but also a pragmatic approach to shared space.
Encourages Bobby to get coffee despite the rain, gives him money, and sends him out with instructions to relax and then call.
Quickly notices Anne's absence and investigates by looking for clues like the cop shirt on the floor.
Handles the situation with Bobby smoothly and confidently, displaying easy social control and situational awareness.
Immediately reacts to gunfire by instructing Anne to dial 911 and moves quickly to assist the wounded Bobby despite personal risk.
Confronts a potentially hostile crowd, identifies himself clearly as police to prevent misunderstanding.
Responds immediately to the rifle shot by crouching at the window and instructing Anne to dial 911 with precise information.
Arms himself quickly and moves toward the scene of the shooting despite the danger.
Takes charge at the crime scene by assessing Bobby's condition and attempting to provide help by checking for a pulse and removing the raincoat.
Leads Kellom out the door decisively to confront him directly about the shooting.
Notices inconsistencies in the patrol, arrest, and vehicle logs indicating tampering across different departments.
Demonstrates deductive reasoning by concluding only someone in command (either Kellom or himself) could have accessed and tampered with those logs.
Expresses suspicion and directly confronts Kellom despite their familial relationship, showing confidence and decisiveness.
Refuses to ignore the situation despite Kellom's suggestion to leave it alone, showing determination and commitment to uncovering the truth.
Catches Mama in his arms when she runs toward him in distress.
Turns his mother back toward the hospital after a traumatic event.
Is frozen over Kellom who is pointing a gun at him, showing hesitation rather than aggression.
Immediately goes for the phone to contact homicide after arrival, showing responsibility but no emotional engagement with Anne.
Responds to Anne’s obsessive focus on the case without engagement or support, simply stating he’s out of ideas.
Hovers frozen over Kellom, holding handcuffs while Kellom points a gun at him
Turns his back to an armed Kellom to comfort Mama and takes charge by escorting her to the hospital
Attempts to follow up on the case by calling homicide detectives to get more information
Expresses running out of ideas regarding the case
Fixes a case against Anne by calling in a favor for a guy in the Property Room.
Admits to being a bagman and justifies minor corruption as part of the system.
Shares a tender kiss and embraces Anne, showing sincere affection.
Find him. Arrest him. (directs action decisively after a confession)
Claims credit for fixing a case using a favor in the Property Room.
Admits to being a bagman taking small bribes but rationalizes it as part of the system.
Shrugs off the question about how smugglers ended up in the canal with a casual guess.
Immediately acts on realizing the narcotics are on the boat, urging Anne to get ready quickly.
Runs through potentially dangerous territory and discreetly accesses a police-authorized dock to investigate the boat.
Realizes that the dope is on the boat quickly after being stunned, then immediately instructs to get dressed and move quickly.
Navigates to a police department dock unauthorized area, unlocks the gate with a key, and locates contraband hidden cleverly under the boat's deck.
Drives confidently through a complex urban warehouse area, showing familiarity with surroundings.
Remy approaches 'La Mordida' cautiously with gun poised, checks surroundings carefully, and examines heroin on the deck for evidence.
Despite instructing Anne to stay put, he allows her to follow him onto the boat, losing some control of the situation.
Points gun at Kellom, threateningly confronts him.
Puts down gun reluctantly when ordered but remains focused and tense.
Holds onto heroin tightly instead of surrendering it immediately.
Takes Anne's arm to help her jump across water gap to dock.
Throws heroin into Dodge and DeSoto's faces to create chance to escape and forces Anne into water for her safety.
Points gun down the stairs with adrenaline pumping, showing readiness and alertness.
Keeps gun down but does not move immediately after being ordered to put it down, carefully holding onto heroin and clenching fist, showing controlled resistance.
Attempts to negotiate a deal under pressure, indicating some level of quick thinking.
Helps Anne jump across from the boat to the dock, showing care and quick physical response.
Throws heroin in opponents’ faces, shoves Anne into water, and escapes by rolling into the water despite being fired on, demonstrating resourcefulness and tactical skill.
Swims under the dock to hide and cautiously scopes out the situation.
Freezes momentarily when hearing a shotgun blast but perseveres to try opening the cabin hatch.
Uses a winch handle to break open the locked cabin hatch despite difficult conditions.
Quickly locates useful items in the dark cabin such as a flare gun and shells.
Uses a flare gun skillfully to incapacitate DeSoto by aiming carefully and effectively.
Performs quick, agile physical movements by jumping between boats and climbing onto the flying bridge under fire.
Attempts to shoot at Dodge despite being under threat of shotgun fire, showing confidence and persistence.
Fails to land a successful shot on Dodge as the flare ricochets, indicating a slight miscalculation.
Fights Dodge despite injury and uses resourcefulness to fire flare gun to save himself and Anne.
Tries to reload a single-shot flare gun with frozen fingers under fire.
Successfully fires a flare that starts a fire on the enemy boat.
Jumps off the cabin cruiser onto the slip to avoid incoming fire.
Quickly loads another shell and fires a flare that kills Dodge.
Delayed slightly by frozen fingers but manages to act effectively under pressure.
Sprints toward Anne to grab her hand and escape the fire together, rolls into an embrace with her, and reassures her by calling themselves 'the Good Guys'.
Sprints to rescue Anne and leaps to shore just before the boat explodes.
Responds confidently when Anne worries about his risky deal with criminals, reassuring her with a grin.
Throws his beeper into the river to avoid detection after an alert.
